November 27, 1983: Fiction
PET SEMATARY, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The new family in town
discovers the horrors that lie in a neighboring cemetery.
POLAND, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Seven centuries of
history in fictional form.
THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace
Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian
monastery.
CHANGES, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) The crises that arise when a
television anchorwoman and a glamorous physician fall in love.
THE SAGA OF BABY DIVINE, by Bette Midler. (Crown, $11.95.) The entertainer
imagines what her infancy was like in a fable lushly illustrated by Todd Schorr.
THE ROBOTS OF DAWN, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $15.95.) A human
detective from Earth investigates the murder of a robot on the planet Aurora.
HOLLYWOOD WIVES, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The
struggle for money and power in Tinsel Town.
THE WICKED DAY, by Mary Stewart. (Morrow, $16.95.) King Arthur, fulfilling a
prophecy made by Merlin, falls into an incestuous relationship.
WHO KILLED THE ROBINS FAMILY?, created by Bill Adler and written by
Thomas Chastain. (Morrow, $9.95.) The publisher offers a $10,000 prize to the
reader who submits the best answer.
THE AUERBACH WILL, by Stephen Birmingham. (Little, Brown, $16.95.) Three
generations of a German-Jewish family in New York.
WINTER'S TALE, by Mark Helprin. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) Heroic
lives in Manhattan between the late 19th century and the year 2000.
MORETA: DRAGONLADY OF PERN, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del Rey/Ballantine,
$14.95.) A battle against ecological disaster on a faraway planet.
RETURN OF THE JEDI, adapted by Joan D. Vinge. (Random House, $6.95.)
Illustrated storybook based on the latest ''Star Wars'' film.
AUGUST, by Judith Rossner. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) The five-year
relationship of two women, a teen-age patient and her analyst.
MONIMBO, by Robert Moss and Arnaud de Borchgrave. (Simon & Schuster,
$16.95.) What happens after Castro unveils a plan to stir racial tension in the
United States.
November 27, 1983
Non-Fiction
MOTHERHOOD: The Second Oldest Profession, by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-
Hill, $12.95.) A humorous look at the biggest on-the-job training program ever.
IN SEARCH OF EXCELLENCE, by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr.
(Harper & Row, $19.95.) Lessons to be learned from well-run American
corporations.
MEGATRENDS, by John Naisbitt. (Warner, $17.50.) Predictions about America in
the next decade based on an analysis of conditions today.
THE BEST OF JAMES HERRIOT. (St. Martin's Press, $19.95.) Selections from
the writings of the Yorkshire veterinarian.
ON WINGS OF EAGLES, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $17.95.) The rescue of two
Americans from an Iranian prison.
VIETNAM: A History, by Stanley Karnow. (Viking, $19.95.) Profusely illustrated
history of the war: tie-in with the current PBS television series.
THE MARY KAY GUIDE TO BEAUTY. (Addison-Wesley, $19.95.) An illustrated
guide for women prepared by the staff of a cosmetic firm.
THE BODY PRINCIPAL, by Victoria Principal. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.)
Exercises for women by a television personality.
TOUGH TIMES NEVER LAST, BUT TOUGH PEOPLE DO! by Robert H. Schuller.
(Thomas Nelson, $12.95.) Inspiration from a Protestant preacher.
FATAL VISION, by Joe McGinniss. (Putnam, $17.95.) The case of Jeffrey
MacDonald, Ivy League graduate, respected physician and convicted killer of his
wife and daughters.
NO MORE HOT FLASHES AND OTHER GOOD NEWS, by Penny W. Budoff.
(Putnam, $14.95.) A health-care handbook for women, written by a Long Island
physician.
THE PETER PAN SYNDROME, by Dan Kiley. (Dodd, Mead, $15.95.) A
psychologist's analysis of the plight of men who have never grown up.
CREATING WEALTH, by Robert G. Allen. (Simon & Schuster, $15.95.) Making
money in real estate.
OUTRAGEOUS ACTS AND EVERYDAY REBELLIONS, by Gloria Steinem. (Holt,
Rinehart & Winston, $14.95.) Essays by a leading feminist writer.
WHILE REAGAN SLEPT, by Art Buchwald. (Putnam, $14.95.) Seven score wry
observations on the Washington scene by the syndicated columnist.
